column2: COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country. If you’re fully vaccinated or not, you are no longer required to present a COVID-19 negative test result to enter Aruba.
column3:
Self-isolation at own accommodation- subject to PCR. The rules apply to vaccinated residents but residents do not need to take out mandatory insurance as part of the embarkation / disembarkation process.
More information is available on the website of the government of Aruba.
column4: Travelers are no longer required to present a proof of vaccination to enter Aruba.
column5:
Latest News: Authorities lift all COVID-19-related entry requirements for all international travelers from 19 March (Travel Agent Central, 18.03.2022)

International Restrictions:
*All travellers: You do not need a visa for stays of up to 3 months. For further information about entry requirements, contact the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands.
You must get approval to travel to Aruba through the embarkation / disembarkation card online before departure. This includes taking out mandatory insurance. Visit the website of the Government of Aruba for the latest information.
If you’re fully vaccinated: If you’re fully vaccinated, you are no longer required to present a COVID-19 negative test result to enter Aruba.
Find out if you qualify as fully vaccinated in Aruba on the website of the Government of Aruba. Proof of vaccination status: Travelers are no longer required to present a proof of vaccination to enter Aruba.
Information on proof of vaccination status can be found on the Aruba website. Residents of Aruba: The rules apply to vaccinated residents but residents do not need to take out mandatory insurance as part of the embarkation / disembarkation process.
If you’re not fully vaccinated: If you’re not fully vaccinated, you are no longer required to present a COVID-19 negative test result to enter Aruba.
More information is available on the website of the government of Aruba. If you’ve had COVID-19 in the past year: If you’re not fully vaccinated but have tested positive for COVID-19 recently you can enter Aruba. You do not need to take an additional COVID-19 test.
Residents of Aruba: The same rules apply to unvaccinated residents.
Children and young people Children aged 12-17 can enter Aruba without a COVID-19 negative test result or proof of vaccination.
Children aged 11 and under do not need to show proof of a negative COVID-19 test or proof of vaccination to enter Aruba.
If you’re transiting through Aruba: Travellers who are transiting without entering Aruba don’t need a negative test. You will need to complete the embarkation / disembarkation process.

Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in Aruba: The Government of Aruba has put measures in place in response to the coronavirus pandemic. such as the mandatory wearing of face masks in all public indoor spaces. All measures and updates can be found on thewebsite of the government of Aruba .
column6: US State Dept. COVID-19 Country Specific Information/ Aruba Traveler Health Requirements/ Foreign travel advice, Gov.UK/
